Directories Charles Dierbach Associate Professor & Interim Program Director, B.S. Computer Science Contact Info Phone: 410-704-3552 Office: YR-495 Email: cdierbach@towson.edu Education Ph.D., Computer Science, University of Delaware, 1991 Areas of Expertise Artificial Intelligence (Analogical Reasoning), Object-Oriented Design, Computer Science Education Scholarship, Creative Activity: Author of the textbook "Introduction to Computer Science Using Python: A Computational Problem-Solving Focus", John Wiley, 2013. Professional Service: Program evaluator for ABET (Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology) Selected Publications and Presentations: James Braman, Charles Dierbach, âUtilizing Virtual Worlds for Personalized Search: Developing the PAsSIVE Framework,â Proceedings of HCI International 2015, August 2-7, 2015, Los Angeles, CA, pp. 3-11. Charles Dierbach, Harry Hochheiser, Samuel Collins, et. al. âA Model for Piloting Pathways for Computational Thinking in a General Education Curriculum,â Proceedings of SIGCSE 2011, March 9-12, 2011, Dallas, TX,  pp. 257-262. James Braman, Charles Dierbach, âUsing Second Life as an Interface for Personalized Search.â In SLActions: Research Conference in the Second Life World. November 18-19, 2010. Braman, J., Dierbach, C. (2010). Second Life as a Context for Personalized Search. 7th International Conference on Cybernetics and Information Technologies, Systems and Applications (CITSA 2010). Oral Presentation. Conference Proceedings, June 29-July 2 2010, Orlando, FL, pp. 230-235. Charles Dierbach, âThe Use of Collaborative Meta-Agents in Multi-Agent Systems,â Technical Report of the AAAI Fall Symposium on Interaction and Emergent Phenomena in Societies of Agents,â October 12-15, 2006, Arlington, Virginia, pp. 82-87. Charles Dierbach, âApplication of the Abstractional Concept Mapping Theory for the Interpretation of Novel Metaphor,â Proceedings of the 6th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking, and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD 2005), May 23-25, Towson, Maryland, pp. 157-162. C. Dierbach, B. Taylor, H. Zhou, and I. Zimand, âExperiences with a CS0 Course Targeted for CS1 Success,â Proceedings of the Thirty-Sixth SIGCSE Conference on Computer Science Education, February 23-27, 2005, St. Louis, MO, pp. 317-320.
